column2: officially the City of Alaminos (Pangasinan: Siyudad na Alaminos; Ilocano: Siudad ti Alaminos; Tagalog: Lungsod ng Alaminos)
column3: is a 4th class city in the  province of Pangasinan
column5: and is known for being the home of the Hundred Islands National Park
column6: which is composed of 124 islands and is located off the coast of Barangay Lucap. According to the 2015 census
column8: 708 people.  The city was named after Juan Alaminos y de Vivar

column1: The Alaminos Airport is currently being built near the city to service the local area.
Alaminos was formerly part of Bolinao
column2: formerly the part of Zambales. In 1747

column1: The Communist Party of the Philippines was founded by Jose Maria Sison in the remote barangay of Dulacac on December 26

column2: signed by President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo on March 5
column4: Alaminos was converted into a city after 85% of the voters favored the ratification in a plebiscite held on March 28

column1: Alaminos was badly hit in May 2009 by Typhoon Emong which damaged many houses in the city
column2: including the roof of the main church. Due to this
column3: several organizations had requested donations and aid to help in restoring the town back to its former self.

column1: Alaminos City is politically subdivided into 39 barangays.
The Galila Hundred Islands Festival is held from March 16 to March 21 every year. Galila means “come” in the vernacular
column2: and the festival includes the 100 Islands Adventure Race.
